text: Awake, psaltery and harp: I myself will awake early.
text_kjv: Awake, psaltery and harp: I myself will awake early.
text_niv: Awake, harp and lyre!I will awaken the dawn.
text_esv: Awake, O harp and lyre! I will awake the dawn!
text_nlt: Wake up, lyre and harp!I will wake the dawn with my song.
text_msg: "Wake, soul! Wake, lute!Wake up, you sleepyhead sun!"
text_nasb: Awake, harp and lyre; I will awaken the dawn!
context: Psalm 108 is a composite psalm, drawing heavily from Psalm 57:7-11 and Psalm 60:5-12. This reuse of earlier material suggests either David’s desire to emphasize certain themes during different periods or a later editor’s intention to highlight consistent aspects of David’s relationship with God. The psaltery (nevel) and harp (kinnor) were stringed instruments commonly used in temple worship during David's time. The psaltery, possibly shaped like a wineskin, often had a larger soundbox and more strings than the harp, typically being plucked, while the harp was sometimes held and strummed. They were integral parts of the Levitical choir's performance, enhancing the atmosphere of worship and praise. The phrase 'I myself will awake early' indicates a commitment to prioritize God and worship before other activities of the day. The historical context suggests a time of national challenge, possibly warfare or external threat, as seen in the borrowed passages from Psalm 60. David, a king leading his people, sought divine assistance and victory, underscoring the importance of seeking God’s favor in times of difficulty. The early morning was considered a prime time for communication with God, reflecting a belief that starting the day with prayer and worship sets the tone for the events ahead. The structure of the psalm reflects a shift from lament to praise, ultimately expressing confidence in God’s power and faithfulness to His covenant people. The use of musical instruments suggests a vibrant and expressive form of worship, emphasizing the emotional and experiential dimensions of faith.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 108:2 speaks to the believer's responsibility to initiate worship and seek God intentionally. 'Awake, psaltery and harp' is not simply about physical instruments, but also about stirring up a spirit of praise and gratitude within the heart. It signifies a deliberate choice to engage with God through music and song, acknowledging His worthiness of adoration. The psalmist's declaration, 'I myself will awake early,' highlights the importance of prioritizing God in one's daily life. It reflects a desire to meet with God before the demands and distractions of the world take over. This early seeking of God underscores a commitment to seeking His guidance and strength for the day ahead. The combination of music and early rising points to a holistic approach to worship, engaging both the emotions and the will. The verse implicitly acknowledges God as the source of awakening, both physically and spiritually. While the psalmist resolves to wake early and play his instruments, it is ultimately God who grants the ability to do so. The early morning represents a time of stillness and quiet, conducive to hearing God's voice and experiencing His presence. The act of waking early also demonstrates a sense of urgency and anticipation in meeting with God, reflecting a deep longing for communion with Him. Theologically, it reinforces the concept of God as actively involved in the lives of His people, responding to their prayers and leading them in His ways. It serves as a call to cultivate a lifestyle of worship and devotion, marked by intentionality and consistency.
application: In practical modern application, Psalm 108:2 challenges us to examine our own habits and priorities regarding worship and prayer. The call to 'awake, psaltery and harp' is a metaphorical urging to cultivate a spirit of praise in our hearts, regardless of our musical abilities. This might involve listening to uplifting music, singing along to hymns, or simply reflecting on God's goodness and expressing gratitude. We should seek to engage our emotions and our intellect in our worship, avoiding mere rote repetition of prayers or songs. The declaration to 'awake early' serves as a reminder to prioritize time with God each day. This doesn't necessarily mean waking up at dawn, but rather setting aside a specific time, even if it's just for a few minutes, to connect with God through prayer, Bible reading, or meditation. This could involve establishing a consistent morning routine, carving out time during lunch breaks, or dedicating evenings to reflection and prayer. The key is to be intentional and consistent in seeking God's presence. We can also apply this verse to our church communities, encouraging corporate worship that is vibrant, engaging, and expressive. Pastors and worship leaders can create environments where people feel free to express their love and adoration for God through music, singing, and other forms of artistic expression. Furthermore, we can apply this principle to our everyday lives, viewing our work, relationships, and hobbies as opportunities to glorify God. By approaching our daily tasks with a spirit of gratitude and excellence, we can transform ordinary moments into acts of worship. The verse also serves as a call to cultivate a sense of urgency and anticipation in our relationship with God, recognizing that He is always present and eager to connect with us. By seeking Him diligently and consistently, we can experience His love, guidance, and provision in every area of our lives.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I thank you for the gift of music and the ability to express my love and praise to you. Stir within me, Lord, a deep desire to seek you early in the morning, before the cares of the world consume my thoughts. Help me to prioritize my time with you, setting aside moments of quiet reflection and prayer. Awaken my heart, like a psaltery and a harp, to sing your praises and to declare your goodness to all the earth. Forgive me for the times when I have neglected your presence and allowed other things to take precedence in my life. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may worship you in spirit and in truth. Guide me by your wisdom, strengthen me by your grace, and fill me with your peace. I pray all of this in the name of your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

faqs.answer: Waking early symbolizes prioritizing God before other daily demands, signifying dedication and anticipation in meeting with Him. It also represents a quieter time for prayer and reflection before the day's distractions begin.
faqs.question: Q1. Why is waking up early emphasized in Psalm 108:2?

faqs.answer: They symbolize a heart filled with praise and a willingness to express worship through music and song. It highlights the importance of engaging our emotions in our worship experience.
faqs.question: Q2. What do the 'psaltery and harp' represent in this verse?

faqs.answer: It's metaphorical. Cultivate a spirit of praise through gratitude, listening to uplifting music, or expressing worship in other creative ways like writing, art, or acts of service.
faqs.question: Q3. How can I 'awake my psaltery and harp' if I'm not musically inclined?

faqs.answer: Schedule dedicated time for prayer and reflection, even if brief. Make worship a regular practice, integrating gratitude and praise into daily activities and viewing work as an offering.
faqs.question: Q4. How can I practically apply this verse to my busy modern life?

faqs.answer: While waking early can be beneficial, the core message is prioritizing God. Find a time that works best for you and be consistent, regardless of the hour. The heart's intention matters most.
